the three former cabinet partners of the Christian Democrats — that is, the
Social Democrats, Liberals and Republicans — now have only 38 Chamber votes.
Three developments in December brought the Pella-party relationship
close to the showdown stage:
First, the Christian Democrats Issued a statement that seemed to be
neutral on the strike of workers in government-operated industries — after
Pella had taken a strong stand against the strike.
Second, former Interior Minister Mario Scelba publicly advocated a re¬
construction of the old D® Gasperi coalition government of Christian Democrats!
Social Democrats, Liberals and Republicans. Scelba emphasized that he was
speaking personally, but he is a director of the party. His speech was in¬
terpreted as criticism of Pella for accepting Monarchist support.
And finally, De Gasperi wrote a stirring call to action for the first
issue of a new Christian Democratic weekly. In the article, he referred to
the Pella cabinet as **a friendly government*** To Pella, this implied that
the party as such felt no responsibility for the government and did not regard
it in any sens© as a party government.
Pella then threatened to resign unless he got full party support. The
party countered by demanding a reshuffle of the"cabinet to make it more of a
Christian Democratic political government* And it was inability to reach
final agreement on the makeup of that government that brought on Pella*s
resignation.
As I say, these things help explain why the crisis between premier and
party probably was inevitable and would have come later If not now. But these
things only begin to explain the much deeper and broader Italian political
crisis of which the fall of Pella is only a symptom. I hope to examine this
more Important question — for Italy and for America — in another special
delivery radio Letter from Italy.
Graham Hovey reporting from Rome for the National Association of
Educational Broadcasters — and this la the NAKB Network.
